# Major Changes
## user-sysmaint-split
Kicksecure Xfce now defaults to a safer split-user model: one account for daily use (`user`) and another for admin tasks (`sysmaint`). This limits the impact of potential malware and strengthens system security. Power users can opt into Unrestricted Admin Mode if needed.
https://www.kicksecure.com/wiki/Sysmaint
https://www.kicksecure.com/wiki/Dev/user-sysmaint-split
https://www.kicksecure.com/wiki/Unrestricted_admin_mode
## System Maintenance Panel
A user-friendly interface for essential system tasks: update software, manage user accounts, configure autologin, change passwords, and run systemcheck, all in one place and designed for sysmaint sessions.
## sudoless
The `user` account no longer has access to `sudo` or other privilege escalation tools. Only dedicated admin accounts like `sysmaint` can perform such actions, reducing the attack surface and improving security.
## privleap
A new security-focused privilege escalation framework replacing `sudo`. It allows only specific, pre-approved actions to be executed with elevated rights, reducing the risk of misuse or exploitation. SUID-free.
## updatecheck
A new background service periodically checks for software updates and alerts users via passive popups. (https://forums.kicksecure.com/t/notifications-about-new-updates/774)
## dummy-dependency
[dummy-dependency](https://www.kicksecure.com/wiki/Debian_Packages#dummy-dependency): Ever wanted to uninstall, for example, Firefox or Thunderbird but ran into the meta package issue? `dummy-dependency` allows the uninstallation of packages that are normally not uninstallable, without removing a (meta) package that depends on the original package.
## systemcheck
Now provides more guidance for [Protection against Physical Attacks](https://www.kicksecure.com/wiki/Protection_Against_Physical_Attacks). New checks include: detection of user-sysmaint-split; on host systems, notification if [full disk encryption (FDE)](https://www.kicksecure.com/wiki/Full_Disk_Encryption) is set up or missing; bootloader password status; and a login security table highlighting passwordless or autologin accounts.
## Virtual Hard Disk Size Increase
https://www.kicksecure.com/wiki/Grow_Virtual_Harddisk is now easier.
## Permission Hardener Improvements
https://www.kicksecure.com/wiki/SUID_Disabler_and_Permission_Hardener v2: major overhaul and improved reliability when adding/removing SUID binaries, which is important for user-sysmaint-split installation/removal.
## Source Code Hardening
* [unicode](https://www.kicksecure.com/wiki/Unicode) verification * [git symlinks](https://www.kicksecure.com/wiki/Git#git_symlinks) verification
# Upcoming Changes
It is planned to no longer install Firefox and Thunderbird by default for the next release.
Rationale: https://www.kicksecure.com/wiki/Dev/Default_Browser
User documentation: https://www.kicksecure.com/wiki/Browser
Instead, there will be a local browser choice application looking similar to [this](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/e/e2/BrowserChoice.gif). (Not a website.) Development plan: https://www.kicksecure.com/wiki/Dev/browser-choice

Major Changes

user-sysmaint-split

Kicksecure Xfce now defaults to a safer split-user model: one account for daily use (user) and another for admin tasks (sysmaint). This limits the impact of potential malware and strengthens system security. Power users can opt into Unrestricted Admin Mode if needed.

Kicksecure – 1 May 25

sysmaint - System Maintenance User

sysmaint

Kicksecure – 2 May 25

user-sysmaint-split

user-sysmaint-split - Role-Based Boot Modes - USER Session / SYSMAINT Session (system maintenance)

Kicksecure – 25 Apr 25

Unrestricted Admin Mode

Kicksecure allows configuration for unrestricted admin mode, enabling the default user account to access privilege escalation tools like sudo and pkexec.

System Maintenance Panel

A user-friendly interface for essential system tasks: update software, manage user accounts, configure autologin, change passwords, and run systemcheck, all in one place and designed for sysmaint sessions.

sudoless

The user account no longer has access to sudo or other privilege escalation tools. Only dedicated admin accounts like sysmaint can perform such actions, reducing the attack surface and improving security.

privleap

A new security-focused privilege escalation framework replacing sudo. It allows only specific, pre-approved actions to be executed with elevated rights, reducing the risk of misuse or exploitation. SUID-free.

updatecheck

A new background service periodically checks for software updates and alerts users via passive popups. (Notifications about new updates)

dummy-dependency

dummy-dependency: Ever wanted to uninstall, for example, Firefox or Thunderbird but ran into the meta package issue? dummy-dependency allows the uninstallation of packages that are normally not uninstallable, without removing a (meta) package that depends on the original package.

systemcheck

Now provides more guidance for Protection against Physical Attacks. New checks include: detection of user-sysmaint-split; on host systems, notification if full disk encryption (FDE) is set up or missing; bootloader password status; and a login security table highlighting passwordless or autologin accounts.

Virtual Hard Disk Size Increase

Virtual Hard Disk Size Increase is now easier.

Permission Hardener Improvements

SUID Disabler and Permission Hardener v2: major overhaul and improved reliability when adding/removing SUID binaries, which is important for user-sysmaint-split installation/removal.

Source Code Hardening

  • unicode verification
  • git symlinks verification

Upcoming Changes

It is planned to no longer install Firefox and Thunderbird by default for the next release.
